messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:38): http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/from-origin/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#from-origin-response-header now has a processing model
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the spec is completely obscure unless one remembers what prefix # means in this flavor of BNF
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:49): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: can the header take a list of multiple origins?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (12:49): where's the definition of this BNF syntax? should it be referenced explicitly?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: it's very sad that CORS doesn't allow multiple origins to be specified
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (12:51): i assumed the #[] meant a comma-separated list or something like that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:51): doesn't know what #[] means
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:52): also, the words origin and same aren't quoted but if they are non-terminals, I don't see expansions, either
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): "if none of" suggests that a list is allowed
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, first version of CORS is not meant for static resources
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, that Gecko used it for fonts without prior discussion with WebApps, well, ...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:55): # is some HTTPism
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:56): makes sense to me to define headers the same way HTTP does
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:56): you're right about same, I should make that an expansion and link origin to some definition in the origin concept draft
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (12:58): "same" = empty list, don't terminate in step 1 and depend on step 5 to allow same-origin only?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:59): terminate means "these steps don't apply"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:59): that should prolly be clarified somewhat
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:59): and "same" is a convenience keyword
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:59): if you can specify an empty header that should probably be allowed too
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (12:59): i mean "From-Origin: same" means #1 won't terminate and step 7 will always terminate?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): right
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): however, before step 7 it will be terminated if it's same origin
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): so that's all good
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:00): i figured that was the idea
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:00): having an empty header would be cleaner but yeah I don't remember if that's allowed, and it might be a bad idea anyway since nothing ever does that
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:01): probably best for empty header to be equivalent to no header
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): actually, WebDAV does that I believe
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:02): XHR also has a distinction between no header and empty string value
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:02): for example, there's no way to specify an empty header with curl
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:02): specifying an empty header removes it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:03): anyway, currently it's not allowed
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:03): # means one or more
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:03): iirc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:03): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: so is From-Origin: same, same conforming?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:03): should it be #[origin | "same"]?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: it would be really nice to link the word "BNF" to whatever IETF flavor of BNF this is
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:04): bnf-fu very rusty
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: also, linking the non-terminals to their expansions would be really nice
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, yes and yes it would; guess I'll do it now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:04): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, no, then same would not be case-sensitive
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:08): http://www.w3.org/TR/2000/REC-xml-20001006#sec-notation a link for EBNF
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:08): this relates not just to HTML but HTTP; should it reference HTTP for what "response header" means? not sure how explicit that's typically made
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:09): maybe case-insensitive is okay
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:09): that definition says "strings" are case-sensitive
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:09): lets not confuse HTTP ABNF with EBNF
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:10): there is also ABNF http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4234
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:10): http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5234
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:11): geez with erratas
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:12): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: XML BNF is readable. Unlike the IETF stuff.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:12): 15.7.1 Denial of Service Attacks on Proxies
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:12): They exist. They are hard to defend against. Research continues.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:12): gotta love a spec that uses the single word "beware" as a sentence
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:13): http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#page-14
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:14): ("page-14" as an anchor? really?)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:14): ietf is kinda fucked up
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:14): writing specs as if the expectation is that everyone's going to print them out ... that's pretty amusing even for 1999
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:15): They regard technologies that postdate the 60s with suspicion and even downright hostility
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:15): "They exist. They are hard to defend against. Research continues. Beware." seems like a good section for other stuff as well, like "Security considerations"
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:17): can I be happy that we're in an age where we no longer feel the need to explicitly reference the ASCII spec from HTML
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:17): http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/from-origin/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#from-origin-response-header refresh
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:18): I thought we did reference the ASCII spec
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:18): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: for http I recommend to look in the direction of httpbis
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:19): They was a whole cycle of the Issue process around it, was there not?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:19): http://tools.ietf.org/wg/httpbis/
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:21): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: perhaps explicitly say that these steps are to be performed as part of the "main step" of fetching
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:21): assuming that's where it goes
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:22): (implying that if F-O aborts the resource, cookies aren't updated, and so on)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:25): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: RFC2119 ref is broken
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:26): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, zevt: reusing the HTTP ABNF makes sense here.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:26): thanks 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, done
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:27): the reference should go to http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc2616.html#rfc.section.2.1
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:27): (not that URI, but RFC 2616, Section 2.1)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:27): httpbis ref is http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-12#page-7 but if it's the same may as well not use an in-progress reference
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:27): you'll also need to steal the definition of OWS from HTTPbis
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:27): &lt 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6> http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#page-14 <- that's the 2616 ref
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:28): http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-12.html#rfc.section.1.2.2
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:28): I guess I'll just say that the ABNF is the same as the Web Origin Concept
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:28): so I can avoid dealing with HTTP references
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:28): it may make sense to steal the details from the new cookie spec
2562560f8ce0d1e9b326af39c5b2ca52 (13:29): actually no: it uses the 5234 syntax
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:29): it now just references ORIGIN
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:30): which in turn hopefully references some correct spec, but it's no longer my problem :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:30): actually, this is not quite correct
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:30): bah

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:32): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the fetch algorithm has a specifically named "main step"; i think it makes sense to refer to it by name to be precise about where in the algorithm it goes
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (13:32): (of course, it won't be when multiple addon-specs are doing that, but heh)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:32): origin-list is space separated :/
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:37): fixed bnf again
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:37): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, yeah, this all needs to be integrated one day
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:38): at some point someone might take everything network and write it all down :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:39): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: please take a look at http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebNotifications/static.html and let me know if you see any problems
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:39): please compare to http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebNotifications/publish/Notifications.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:39): the main difference is where/how the Notification constructor is defined
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:41): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, that is wrong
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:41): Berjon's current JS respec does not seem to provide any way to handle the constructor differently than normal methods
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (13:41): Philip`: hi there, can we chat about how reports are gathered with your test harness?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:41): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, now it says there's a method Notification on the Notification object
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:41): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e; so now I have to hack fricking respec more
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:42): yeah, I know
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:42): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, respec2 doesn't handle it either? sounds painful
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:42): I can't imagine this is the first spec using respec that has needed to document a constructtor
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:42): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, I'm fine with publishing as-is though, maybe with a note
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:43): or maybe berjon knows a cure
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:43): nah, I can fix it today
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:43): maybe
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:43): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, added main step
